fields.headline: In brief
fields.bodyText: Nortel sheds more staff Nortel Networks, the telecommunications equipment maker, yesterday announced plans to cut a further 3,500 jobs, about 10% of its workforce. Nortel has cut more than 60,000 staff since 2000. BT lands £32m Nats deal BT yesterday won a £32m contract to build a network to support all the radar, communications and air traffic control centres operated by National Air Traffic Services. The system will play a crucial role in guaranteeing safety and security ahead of a significant expansion in air traffic over the next eight years. FSA relaxes targets The Financial Services Authority yesterday relaxed its tough proposals for life insurers over with-profits policies, which have seen bonus payments slashed. The FSA is forcing insurers to publish target ranges for bonus payments after payouts were destroyed by weakening stock markets. After lobbying from the industry, however, the regulator will not require insurers to set targets limiting the amount payouts change each year. HSBC buys into Brazil HSBC has agreed to buy the consumer finance operations of Brazil's Indusval Multistock Group for about $124m (£68m). Indusval's consumer finance business in Brazil operates in two main areas - store loans, through 3,250 retailers, and personal loans, through its network of 61 branches' 1.1m active customers. Parmalat sues CSFB Parmalat yesterday pushed on with its plan to recover billions of euros from banks that did deals with the now insolvent foods group, saying it had sued Credit Suisse First Boston for about €250m (£169m) over a 2002 bond deal.
